title: Welcome
description: Some information about me and my interests.
contents: Welcome to my blog! I am a conservation biologist looking to solve the complex environmental problems of today’s world. These posts contain examples of my previous work; feel free to click around and take a look for yourself.

title: Visualizing CO2 emissions from food waste across countries
description: A graphic depicting per capita carbon dioxide emissions from food consumption of the 15 highest-emitting countries.
contents:
code

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)

library(tidyverse)
library(calecopal)





code

#read in the data from github
food_consumption <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2020/2020-02-18/food_consumption.csv')

#creating a subset with the 15 countries with highest total annual per capita CO2 emissions from food consumption
consumption_subset <- food_consumption %>% 
  group_by(country) %>% #grouping by country
  summarize(total_co2 = sum(co2_emmission, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% #creating summary table with total co2 emissions per country
  slice_max(order_by = total_co2, n = 15) %>%  #keeping only the top 15 countries
  mutate(country = fct_reorder(country, total_co2)) #making country a factor with level order based on total CO2 emissions 

#making a finalized plot of top 15 co2 emitting countries
ggplot(data = consumption_subset, aes(x = total_co2, y = country)) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = country)) + #color-coding by country
  scale_fill_manual(values = cal_palette(name = "bigsur", n = 15, type = "continuous")) + #selecting palette
  labs(x = "Annual CO2 emissions from food consumption (kg CO2/person/year)", #adding labels
       y = "Country") + 
  theme_light() + #adding theme
  theme(legend.position = "none") #removing legend




Figure 1: Total annual per capita CO2 emissions from food consumption by country (in kg CO2/person/year), sorted in descending order and color-coded by country. Countries with lower CO2 emissions are at the bottom of the graph and are lighter in color, with color darkening toward the top as total CO2 emissions increase. Data: nu3 Nutrition Experts 2019; Kulma 2020.
Data citation
Original source: nu3 Nutrition Experts. 2019. “Food carbon footprint index 2018”.https://www.nu3.de/blogs/nutrition/food-carbon-footprint-index-2018
Tidy data source: Kulma, Kasia. 2020. “Webscraping with R - from messy & unstructured to blisfully tidy”. https://r-tastic.co.uk/post/from-messy-to-tidy/

title: Mono Lake water levels
description: A visualization depicting Mono Lake water levels through time, with relevant lake levels and historical events labeled.
contents:
code

lake_levels <- read_csv(here("_posts", "2022-03-14-monolake", "data", "mono_lake_annual_levels.csv"), skip = 5) %>% 
  clean_names()

ggplot(data = lake_levels, aes(x = year, y = lake_level_feet_above_sea_level)) +
  geom_ribbon(data = lake_levels %>% #adding shading between the stable line and the measurements
                filter(lake_level_feet_above_sea_level <= 6392), aes(ymin = lake_level_feet_above_sea_level, ymax = 6392), fill = "firebrick" , alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_line() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 1850, to = 2017, by = 20)) + #scaling the x axis
  geom_hline(yintercept = 6377, color = "tan4", linetype = "twodash") + #adding land bridges line
  annotate("text", x = 1880, y = 6379, label = "Emergence of land bridges (6377 ft)", color = "tan4") + #adding land bridges label
  geom_hline(yintercept = 6392, color = "mediumblue", linetype = "longdash") + #adding stable level line
  annotate("text", x = 1865, y = 6394, label = "Stable level (6392 ft)", color = "mediumblue") + #adding stable level label
  geom_hline(yintercept = 6350, color = "dodgerblue4", linetype = "twodash") + #adding salinity line
  annotate("text", x = 1875, y = 6352, label = "Salinity above 150 g/L (6350 ft)", color = "dodgerblue4") + #adding salinity label
  theme_light() +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Lake Level (ft above sea level)", #adding labels and title
       title = "Mono Lake water levels between 1850 and 2017") +
  annotate(geom = "point", x = 1941, y = 6417.0, color = "blue4", size = 2) + #adding a point to the graph
  annotate("segment", #adding a line coming out from that point
           x = 1942, xend = 1941, 
           y = 6424, yend = 6417.0,
           colour = "blue4", 
           size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 1964, y = 6426, size = 3, label = "LA DWP begins diverting water 
           from Mono Lake’s tributary streams", color = "blue4") + #adding a label at the end of that line
  annotate(geom = "point", x = 1981, y = 6372.30, color = "blue4", size = 2) + #point
  annotate("segment", #line
           x = 1975, xend = 1981, 
           y = 6369, yend = 6372.30,
           colour = "blue4", 
           size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 1956, y = 6369, size = 3, label = "Mono Lake Tufa State 
           Natural Reserve created", color = "blue4") + #label
  annotate(geom = "point", x = 1983, y = 6378.60, color = "blue4", size = 2) + #point
  annotate("segment", #line
           x = 1985, xend = 1983, 
           y = 6360, yend = 6378.60,
           colour = "blue4", 
           size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 1985, y = 6356, size = 3, label = "CA obligated to
           protect Mono Lake", color = "blue4") + #label
  annotate(geom = "point", x = 1994, y = 6374.60, color = "blue4", size = 2) + #point
  annotate("segment", #line
           x = 1995, xend = 1994, 
           y = 6365, yend = 6374.60,
           colour = "blue4", 
           size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 2000, y = 6364, size = 3, label = "Decision 1631", color = "blue4") + #label
  annotate(geom = "point", x = 1998, y = 6384.30, color = "blue4", size = 2) + #point
  annotate("segment", #line
           x = 2005, xend = 1998, 
           y = 6375, yend = 6384.30,
           colour = "blue4", 
           size = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", x = 2010, y = 6372, size = 3, label = "Restoration orders 
  98-05 and 98-07", color = "blue4") + #label
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold")) #bolding and centering the title




Figure 1: Visualization of Mono Lake water levels (in feet above sea level) from 1850 to 2017, with relevant lake level and event annotations. The necessary stable level of the lake required to protect Mono Lake’s public trust values (6392 ft) is marked by a blue dashed line. For years where the recorded water level was below the stable level, the shaded red area marks how far below the stable level it was. The brown two-dashed line (6377ft) marks the lake level at which land bridges emerge between the mainland and islands, allowing predators to access important bird nesting sites. The lowest, darker blue two-dashed line (6350 ft) marks the lake level at which salinity would be high enough (150 g/L) to acutely impact brine shrimp and brine flies, the critical food resources for aquatic birds using Mono Lake, and reduce bird populations. The large decrease in lake levels begins in 1941, when the LA Department of Water & Power (DWP) began diverting water from Mono Lake’s tributary streams south to meet LA water demands. In 1981, the Mono Lake Tufa State Natural Reserve was created, and shortly after in 1983 the California Supreme Court ruled that the state has an obligation to protect places such as Mono Lake. In 1994, the State Water Board’s Decision 1631 set a lake level of 6392 feet to protect Mono Lake’s public trust values, required permanent streamflows for Mono Basin streams, and ordered DWP to restore streams and waterfowl habitat damaged as a result of diversions. Finally, in 1998, the State Water Board issued restoration orders 98-05 and 98-07, which required the DWP to implement a restoration plan for the Mono Basin’s streams and waterfowl habitat. The orders mandated raising Mono Lake to 6392 feet, improving existing freshwater ponds for migrating birds, and taking stream restoration measures such as implementing streamflow patterns based on the natural hydrograph.

title: Exploratory report on juvenile snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest
description: This code explores weight and other body measurements of juvenile showshoe hares in the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest.
contents:
Contents
Introduction
Data and analyses
Juvenile hare initial investigation
Annual juvenile hare trap counts
Takeaway

Visualizing juvenile hare weights by sex and site
Takeaway

Weight comparison of juvenile snowshoe hares by sex
Takeaway

Exploring the relationship between juvenile weight and hind foot length
Takeaway


Summary
Citation



code

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, results = TRUE, warning = FALSE, message = FALSE)

library(tidyverse)
library(here)
library(lubridate)
library(dplyr)
library(effsize)
library(kableExtra)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(broom)



Introduction
This report provides an exploratory overview of differences in juvenile weights for snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) trapped between 1999 and 2012 at three interior forest sites at The Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest (BCEF). Annual juvenile hare trap counts are compared across the years of the study, juvenile hare body weights are compared between sexes and across all three study sites, and the relationship between hind foot length and juvenile hare body weight is explored via a simple linear regression.
Data and analyses
Snowshoe hare body measurements were collected and made available by Dr. Knut Kielland and colleagues at the at the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. The BCEF exists within the Bonanza Creek Long-Term Ecological Research site at the University of Alaska Fairbanks Institute of Arctic Biology. It is a 50 km\(^2\) experimental forest located approximately 20 km southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska on land owned by the State of Alaska. (Kielland et al 2017). The data contain observations for 3197 unique snowshoe hares, both juvenile and adult, collected at three sites between 1998 and 2012. Juvenile observations begin in 1999, so that is the earliest year for the data used this exploratory report. The three sites are listed below, along with identifying data:
Bonanza Riparian: A flood zone along the Tanana River. Bonanza Riparian consisted of willow (Salix spp.), paper birch (Betula papyrifera), alder (Alnus spp.), white spruce (Picea glauca), fireweed (Epilobium augustifolium) and several grasses.
Bonanza Mature: A mature black spruce forest approximately 1 km inland from the river and 2 km from the riparian plot. Consisted of stands of mature white spruce, paper birch, and alder, as well as black spruce (Picea mariana), Labrador tea (Ledum groenlandicum), willows, and prickly rose (Rosa acicularis).
Bonanza Black Spruce: Located in a mature lowland black spruce stand.
Exploratory data visualization and analysis is carried out for juvenile snowshoe hare observations. A basic histogram is used to observe the number of juvenile hares trapped annually during the course of the study, and a faceted, color-coded box plot is used to explore juvenile hare weights grouped by sex and by site. Data tables are used to numerically compare summary statistics for hare weights grouped by sex and site, and grouped only by sex. A two-sample t-test using a significance level (α) of 0.05 is used to statistically compare the difference in mean weights between male and female juvenile hares, and the difference between male and female hare weights is also described by Cohen’s d effect size. The relationship between hind foot length and juvenile hare body mass is explored by simple linear regression. All analyses are in R version 4.1.1 using RStudio version 1.4.1717.
Juvenile hare initial investigation
Annual juvenile hare trap counts
This basic histogram visually explores the total number of juvenile hares trapped in each year of the study.


code

#read in the hare data
bonanza_hares <- read.csv(here("_posts", "2022-03-14-hares", "data", "bonanza_hares.csv"))

#create a dataframe with only juvenile hare counts

juv_hares_year <- bonanza_hares %>% 
  filter(age == "j") %>% #keeping only observations for juvenile hares
  mutate(date = mdy(date), #change date column to have class "Date"
         year = year(date)) %>% #add a new column named "year" with just the observation years
 group_by(year) #telling R to group the data by year

#visualize this data with a bar graph

ggplot(data = juv_hares_year, aes(x = year)) + #making a ggplot of hare weights by year
  geom_bar(fill = "skyblue4") + #designating it as a histogram and updating color
  labs(x = "Year", #adding labels
       y = "Juvenile Hares Observed") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 1999, to = 2021, by = 1)) + #adjusting scale to be by year
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) #adjusting x axis text to be at 90 degrees 



code

#make a new object containing only counts of juvenile hares by year
juv_hares_annual_count <- juv_hares_year %>% 
  count(year)



Figure 1: The total number of juvenile snowshoe hares observed each year at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site between 1999 and 2012. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
Takeaway
The maximum number of juvenile hares trapped in one year during this period was 126 during 1999, and the minimum number of juvenile hares trapped in one year was 0 during 2002 and 2009. The mean number of juvenile hares trapped per year is 31.5, and the median is 18.5. The annual number of juvenile hares trapped generally decreased per year, particularly between 1999 and 2000. It is important to note than sampling effort can have an impact on the apparent number of trapped individuals. In future analyses, to ensure that data trends are a result of trends in the populations, sampling effort should be standardized between years (i.e., an equal number of traps should be set, for an equal number of days).
Visualizing juvenile hare weights by sex and site
These faceted and color-coded box plots visually compare juvenile hare weights (in grams) by sex and by site. The table below numerically compares summary statistics of juvenile hare weights grouped by these same factors (sex and site).


code

#formatting the data so labels show up appropriately in graph
juv_hares_boxplot_data <- juv_hares_year %>% 
  group_by(sex, grid) %>% #grouping by these factors
  mutate(sex = case_when( #replacing the shortened values in the dataset with full names
    sex %in% "f" ~ "Female",
    sex %in% "m" ~ "Male",
    sex %in% NA ~ "Unknown")) %>% 
  mutate(grid = case_when(  #replacing the shortened values in the dataset with full names
    grid %in% "bonbs" ~ "Bonanza Black Spruce",
    grid %in% "bonmat" ~ "Bonanza Mature",
    grid %in% "bonrip" ~ "Bonanza Riparian"))

#make a boxplot of juvenile hare weights by site, with scatterplot points mapped to it
ggplot(data = juv_hares_boxplot_data, aes(x = sex, y = weight, fill = sex)) + #making the plot
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("mistyrose", "lightsteelblue", "lightgrey")) + #designating color coding
  geom_boxplot(outlier.color = "black") + #designating outlier point color and type of plot
  geom_beeswarm(shape = 1, alpha = 0.65, aes(color = sex)) + #mapping the scatterplot points to the box plot
  scale_color_manual(values = c("palevioletred", "steelblue", "gray42")) + #designating color coding
  facet_wrap(~grid) + #grouping by site
  labs(y = "Body weight (g)", #adding labels
       x = "Sex") +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point", shape = 18, size = 2.5) + #adjusting point size, shape, opacity
  theme(legend.position = "none") #removing legend




Figure 2: A boxplot of body weights of juvenile snowshoe hares observed at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site between 1999 and 2012, grouped by sex and by observation site. Individual data points are overlaid to show general trends. Box endpoints indicate the 25th and 75th percentile values; the middle black line and black diamond within the box indicate the median and mean value for each sex, respectively. The whiskers correspond to the maximum (upper whisker) and minimum (lower whisker) values, not including outliers (solid black dots). Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
Table 1: Summary statistics table of body weight data of juvenile snowshoe hares observed at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site between 1999 and 2012, grouped by sex and by observation site. Only one dead hare of unknown sex was recovered from the Bonanza Black Spruce site, and no weight was taken, so a median value cannot be calculated once NA values are removed (hence the NaN “Not a Number” value recorded in the table), and other values are NA. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


code

#make a summary table with juvenile hare weights by sex and site

juv_hares_sex_site_table <- juv_hares_boxplot_data %>% #start with the boxplot data (so groups have proper names)
  group_by(sex, grid) %>% #grouping by sex and site (grid)
  summarize(Mean = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), #designating a column for means
            Median = median(weight, na.rm  =TRUE), #and one for medians
            Standard_Deviation = sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE), #and one for standard deviations
            Count = n()) %>% #and finally one for counts
  kable(digits = c(2, 2, 2, 2), #setting the number of digits for each column; similar to `round()`)
        col.names = c("Sex", "Site", "Mean (g)", "Median (g)", "Standard Deviation (g)", "Sample Size"), #naming columns
        align = "llcccc") %>% #aligning the values centrally except for the species column (left aligned)
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, position = "center") %>%  #setting it to not take up the full page width and be center aligned, creating alternate shading for rows to make it easier to see
    row_spec(c(1,2,3,7,8,9), background = "lightgrey")


#call up the table

juv_hares_sex_site_table



Sex


Site


Mean (g)


Median (g)


Standard Deviation (g)


Sample Size


Female


Bonanza Black Spruce


1022.06


1060

35

Bonanza Mature


808.19


685


361.12

Bonanza Riparian


824.15

1073.08

Takeaway
Median and mean juvenile body weights were higher for male snowshoe hares than female snowshoe hares at all three sites. Female hares tended to have more body weight values in the upper quartile (between the median and the 75th percentile), while male hares tended to have more body weight values in the lower quartile (between the median and the 25th percentile). Male and female hares are largest at Bonanza Black Spruce, with higher mean and median body masses than hares at the other two sites. Body weight measurements of juvenile hares of unknown sex only occurred at the Bonanza Riparian and Bonanza Mature sites, and hares of unknown sex had much lower mean and median weights than either male or female hares at the Bonanza Riparian site.
Weight comparison of juvenile snowshoe hares by sex
Body weight (in grams) is numerically compared between the sexes in this summary statistics table. Sampling site is not included as a variable, but should be investigated in the future. A Cohen’s d test and a Welch two-sample t-test were run on the samples of male and female hare weights to determine the size and significance of the impact of sex on juvenile hare body weight. Diagnostic plots (not included) revealed the data and residuals to be normally distributed.
Table 2: Summary statistics table of body weight data of juvenile snowshoe hares observed at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site between 1999 and 2012, grouped by sex. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).


code

#make a summary table with juvenile hare weights by sex

juv_hares_sex_table <- juv_hares_boxplot_data %>% #start with the boxplot data (so groups have proper names)
  filter(sex %in% c("Male", "Female")) %>% #filtering for only male and female observations
  group_by(sex) %>% #grouping by sex 
  summarize(Mean = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), #designating a column for means
            Median = median(weight, na.rm  =TRUE), #and one for medians
            Standard_Deviation = sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE), #and one for standard deviations
            Count = n()) %>% #and finally one for counts
  kable(digits = c(2, 2, 2, 2), #setting the number of digits for each column; similar to `round()`)
        col.names = c("Sex", "Mean (g)", "Median (g)", "Standard Deviation (g)", "Sample Size"), #naming columns
        align = "llcccc") %>% #aligning the values centrally except for the species column (left aligned)
  kable_styling(full_width = FALSE, position = "center", bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover")) #setting it to not take up the full page width and be center aligned, creating alternate shading for rows to make it easier to see

#call up the table
juv_hares_sex_table



Sex


Mean (g)


Median (g)


Standard Deviation (g)


Sample Size


Female


855.39


825


292.25


200


Male


945.86


990


333.22


163


Takeaway
Mean weight for male hares (945.86 g) is 90.47 g (10.58%) larger than mean weight for female hares (855.39 g). According to the Cohen’s d test and the two-sample t-test run on the data, the effect of sex on body weight is small (Cohen’s d = 0.29) but statistically significant (Welch Two Sample t-test: p = 0.0071, t(325.02) = 2.71). A p value of 0.0071 suggests that there is a 0.71 percent chance that if our male and female hare populations did have the same mean, the sample means would be at least 90.47 g different.
Exploring the relationship between juvenile weight and hind foot length
This simple linear regression explores the correlation between juvenile hare hind foot length (in millimeters) and weight (in grams). A correlation test was run to find the Pearson’s r value. Exploratory diagnostic plots (not included) raised some concerns, which are discussed in the takeaway section below.


code

#creating a plot of hind foot length (x) vs. juv weight (y)

ggplot(data = juv_hares_year, aes(x = hindft, #creating the plot
                            y = weight)) +
  geom_point(shape = 18, size = 2) + #designating the plot and adjusting point shape and size
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "turquoise4") + #adding a linear regression trendline and changing color
  labs(x = "Hind Foot Length (mm)", #adding labels
       y = "Weight (g)")



code

#set up the model equation
juv_hare_lm <- lm(data = juv_hares_year, weight ~ hindft)

#make it tidy
juv_hare_lm_tidy <- tidy(juv_hare_lm)

#use glance to see summary statistics of the lm
juv_hare_lm_glance <- glance(juv_hare_lm)

#get Pearson's R
juv_hares_pearson <- cor.test(data = juv_hares_year, juv_hares_year$hindft, juv_hares_year$weight)



Figure 3: Relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) of juvenile snowshoe hares observed at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site between 1999 and 2012. Diamonds correspond to individual hare observations. Linear model summary: \(\beta_1\) = 9.52 g/mm, p < 0.001, R\(^2\) = 0.3, Pearson’s r = 0.55. Data: Kielland et al. (2017).
Takeaway
Hind foot length appears linearly related with juvenile snowshoehare body weight. The effect of hind foot length on juvenile hare weight is moderate (Pearson’s r = 0.55) but statistically significant (p < 0.001). The slope of the linear model is 9.52, which suggests an expected average increase in body mass of 9.52 g for each 1 mm increase in hind foot length if all other factors are held constant. Despite a low p value, an R\(^2\) value of just 0.3 suggests that only 30% of the variance in juvenile snowshoe hare weight can be accounted for by this model. This is a low number, and suggests that a linear model with only hind foot length as the independent variable may not be the best way to explore this data.
Observing diagnostic plots of this data solidifies this concern that a simple linear model is not the best fit. The residual vs. fitted plot revealed the data to be heteroscedastic, with residual values increasing as weight increases. The Q-Q diagnostic plot also revealed residuals that are not very normally distributed, particularly at low weights. These diagnostic plots suggest that we are missing important variables in our model, and perhaps a multiple regression or another model would be a more appropriate fit. It would be wise to explore changes in body weight as they relate to sex and site, since exploratory boxplots (Figure 2) suggested that these factors may have an effect on juvenile hare weights.
Summary
Exploratory data analysis reveals the following:
The number of juvenile snowshoe hares observed each year at the Bonanza Creek Long Term Ecological Research site generally decreased between 1999 and 2012.
Male juvenile snowshoe hares have larger mean and median weights than female juvenile snowshoe hares at all three sites; while the effect size of sex on body weight is small, it is statistically significant.
Juvenile hares are larger at the Bonanza Black Spruce site.
Juvenile hare weight is positively correlated with hind foot length; the relationship by a simple linear regression model is moderate but statistically significant, with a slope of 9.52 g/mm. However, diagnostic exploratory plots reveal that a simple linear model is likely not the best way to explore this data, and the R\(^2\) value is low (0.3), indicating that juvenile hare body weight is not well predicted by this simple linear model.
Next steps to take include:
Multiple linear regression should be run to understand the affects of sex and site in addition to hind foot length on juvenile hare weights.
Adult hare weight data should be analyzed in a similar fashion to this report in order to assess how well hares are surviving at the different sites.
Citation
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative.
Link to metadata.
